title: 113_hr4333
content: SECTION 1 amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow computer technology and equipment as qualified higher education expenses for Section 529 accounts. The amendment removes the restriction on the years 2009 and 2010 and specifies that the technology must be used primarily by the beneficiary. These changes apply to expenses incurred after December 31, 2010. SEC. 2 amends section 529(b) of the Internal Revenue Code to allow investment direction more frequently than 4 times per year. The heading for paragraph (4) is changed to "Limited investment direction". Effective for years starting after December 31, 2013. SEC. 3 eliminates distribution aggregation requirements. SEC. 3 eliminates distribution aggregation requirements for calculating earnings portion of any distribution. SEC. 4 allows contribution of previously distributed amounts in case of withdrawal from school. SEC. 4 introduces a special rule for contributions related to withdrawals from school, allowing beneficiaries to recontribute refunded education expenses to a qualified tuition program within 60 days. The amendment made by this section applies to distributions after December 31, 2013. SEC. 5. SPECIAL ROLLOVER TO ROTH IRA FROM LONG-TERM QUALIFIED TUITION PROGRAM. Special rollover to Roth IRA from long-term qualified tuition program allows for a distribution from a qualified tuition program after being maintained for 10 years to be rolled over to a Roth IRA within 60 days of the distribution. A distribution from a qualified tuition program can be rolled over into a Roth IRA within 60 days, with a limit of $25,000 or the total amount contributed to the program before. The amendments made by this section allow for qualified rollover contributions from a covered qualified tuition program to a Roth IRA, effective for distributions after December 31, 2013.
